standard_metadata.standard_description: Explaining why multiplying a given number by a fraction greater than 1 results in a product greater than the given number (recognizing multiplication by whole numbers greater than 1 as a familiar case); explaining why multiplying a given number by a fraction less than 1 results in a product smaller than the given number; and relating the principle of fraction equivalence a/b = (n × a)/(n × b) to the effect of multiplying a/b by 1.

question.content: **Compare using $>,<,$ or $=$.**   *Hint: Try to solve without multiplying.*  $\dfrac14 \times5{,}000~$  $5{,}000$

hints.content: How does $\purpleE{{\dfrac14}\times 5{,}000}$ compare to $5{,}000$ on a number line?  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, a starting tick mark at 0, a tick mark labeled one-fourth times 5000, two unlabeled tick marks, and an ending tick mark at 5000.

hints.content: Since $\purpleE{\dfrac14}<1$, multiplying $5{,}000$ by $\purpleE{\dfrac14}$ will scale $5{,}000$ down to a smaller number.

question.content: **Compare using $>,<,$ or $=$.**   *Hint: Try to solve without multiplying.*  $60\times\dfrac23~$  $60$

hints.content: How does $\purpleE{60\times\dfrac23}$ compare to $60$ on a number line?  [[☃ image 2]]

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, a starting tick mark at 0, an unlabeled tick mark, a tick mark labeled 60 times two-thirds, and an ending tick mark at 60.

hints.content: Since $\purpleE{\dfrac23}<1$, multiplying $60$ by $\purpleE{\dfrac23}$ will scale $60$ down to a smaller number.
$60\times\dfrac23 < 60$

question.content: **Compare using $>,<,$ or $=$.**   *Hint: Try to solve without multiplying.*  $15$  $\dfrac25\times15$

hints.content: How does $15$ compare to $\purpleE{\dfrac25\times15}$ on a number line?  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, a starting tick mark at 0, an unlabeled tick mark, a tick mark labeled two-fifths times 15, two unlabeled tick marks, and an ending tick mark at 15.

hints.content: Since $\purpleE{\dfrac25}<1$, multiplying $15$ by $\purpleE{\dfrac25}$ will scale $15$ down to a smaller number.
$15 > \dfrac25\times15$

question.content: **Compare using $>,<,$ or $=$.**   *Hint: Try to solve without multiplying.*  $20$  $20\times\dfrac65$

hints.content: How does $20$ compare to $\purpleE{20\times\dfrac65}$ on a number line?  [[☃ explanation 1]]   [[☃ image 2]]

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, a starting tick mark at 0, four unlabeled tick marks, a tick mark labeled 20, a tick mark labeled 20 times six-fifths, three unlabeled tick marks and an ending tick mark at 40.

hints.content: Since $\purpleE{\dfrac65}>1$, multiplying $20$ by $\purpleE{\dfrac65}$ will scale $20$ up to a larger number.
$20<20\times\dfrac65$

question.content: **Compare using $>,<,$ or $=$.**   *Hint: Try to solve without multiplying.*  $\dfrac77 \times36~$  $36$

hints.content: Let's remember that $\purpleE{\dfrac77}=\blueE1$.
Therefore:  $\begin{align} \purpleE{\dfrac77}\times36&=\blueE1\times36\\\\ &=36 \end{align}$
$\dfrac77\times36=36$ because we are multiplying $36$ by a fraction that is *equal to* $1$.
$\dfrac77\times36=36$

question.content: **How will the product of $7\times\dfrac54$  compare to $7$, and why?**

options.content: It will be less because we are multiplying $7$ by a fraction that is *less than* $1$.
It will be equal because we are multiplying $7$ by a fraction that is *equal to* $1$.
It will be greater because we are multiplying $7$ by a fraction that is *greater than* $1$.

hints.content: How does $\purpleE{7 \times \dfrac54}$ compare to $7$ on a number line?  [[☃ explanation 1]]   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, a starting tick mark at 0, three unlabeled tick marks, a tick mark labeled 7, a tick mark labeled seven times five-fourths, two unlabeled tick marks, and an ending tick mark at 14.

hints.content: Since $\purpleE{\dfrac54}>1$, multiplying $7$ by $\purpleE{\dfrac54}$ will scale $7$ up to a larger number.
$7\times\dfrac54>7$
$7\times\dfrac54$ will be greater than $7$ because we are multiplying $7$ by a fraction that is *greater than* $1$.

question.content: **How will the product of $72\times\dfrac37$  compare to $72$, and why?**

options.content: It will be less because we are multiplying $72$ by a fraction that is *less than* $1$.
It will be equal because we are multiplying $72$ by a fraction that is *equal to* $1$.
It will be greater because we are multiplying $72$ by a fraction that is *greater than* $1$.

hints.content: How does $\purpleE{72 \times \dfrac37}$ compare to $72$ on a number line?   [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, a starting tick mark at 0, two unlabeled tick marks, a tick mark labeled 72 times three-sevenths, three unlabeled tick marks, and an ending tick mark at 72.

hints.content: Since $\purpleE{\dfrac37}<1$, multiplying $72$ by $\purpleE{\dfrac37}$ will scale $72$ down to a smaller number.
$72\times\dfrac37 < 72$
$72\times\dfrac37$ will be less than $72$ because we are multiplying $72$ by a fraction that is *less than* $1$.

question.content: **How will the product of $16\times\dfrac33$  compare to $16$, and why?**

options.content: It will be less because we are multiplying $16$ by a fraction that is *less than* $1$.
It will be equal because we are multiplying $16$ by a fraction that is *equal to* $1$.
It will be greater because we are multiplying $16$ by a fraction that is *greater than* $1$.

hints.content: We know that $\purpleE{\dfrac33}=\blueE1$.
Therefore:  $\begin{align} 16\times\purpleE{\dfrac33}&=16\times\blueE1\\\\ &=16 \end{align}$
$16\times\dfrac33 =16$
$16\times\dfrac33$ will be equal to $16$ because we are multiplying $16$ by a fraction that is *equal to* $1$.

question.content: **How will the product of $\dfrac75\times 15$  compare to $15$, and why?**

options.content: It will be less because we are multiplying $15$ by a fraction that is *less than* $1$.
It will be equal because we are multiplying $15$ by a fraction that is *equal to* $1$.
It will be greater because we are multiplying $15$ by a fraction that is *greater than* $1$.

hints.content: How does $\purpleE{\dfrac75 \times 15}$ compare to $15$ on a number line?   [[☃ explanation 1]]  [[☃ image 1]]

images.alt: A number line that has, moving left to right, a starting tick mark at 0, four unlabeled tick marks, a tick mark labeled 15, one unlabeled tick mark, a tick mark labeled seven-fifths times 15, two unlabeled tick marks, and an ending tick mark at 30.

hints.content: Since $\purpleE{\dfrac75}>1$, multiplying $15$ by $\purpleD{\dfrac75}$ will scale $15$ up to a larger number.
$\dfrac75 \times 15 > 15$
$\dfrac75 \times 15$ will be greater than $15$ because we are multiplying $15$ by a fraction that is *greater than* $1$.

question.content: **How will the product of $45$  compare to $45\times\dfrac{250}{250}$, and why?**

options.content: It will be less because we are multiplying $45$ by a fraction that is *less than* $1$.
It will be equal because we are multiplying $45$ by a fraction that is *equal to* $1$.
It will be greater because we are multiplying $45$ by a fraction that is *greater than* $1$.

hints.content: We know that $\purpleE{\dfrac{250}{250}}=\blueE1$.
Therefore:  $\begin{align} 45\times\purpleE{\dfrac{250}{250}}&=45\times\blueE1\\\\ &=45 \end{align}$
$45\times\dfrac{250}{250}$ will be equal to $45$ because we are multiplying $45$ by a fraction that is *equal to* $1$.

If we multiply $17$ by $\blueE{\text{any number greater than } 1}$, $17$ will be scaled up to a number that is greater than $17$.  Which expressions multiply $17$ by a$\blueE{\text{ number greater than } 1}?$
$17 \times {\dfrac3{8}}$ :  ${\dfrac38}<1$, so $17$ will be scaled down to a number less than $17$.
$17 \times {\dfrac1{4}}$ :  ${\dfrac14}<1$, so $17$ will be scaled down to a number less than $17$.
$17 \times \dfrac9{8} $ :  $\blueE{\dfrac9{8} > 1}$, so $17$ will be scaled up to a number greater than $17$.
$17 \times \dfrac{12}{8} $ :  $\blueE{\dfrac{12}{8} > 1}$, so $17$ will be scaled up to a number greater than $17$.
The following expressions are greater than $17$ :  * $17 \times \dfrac9{8} $  * $17 \times \dfrac{12}{8}$

If we multiply $95$ by $\blueE{\text{any number less than } 1}$, $95$ will be scaled down to a number that is less than $95$.  Which expressions multiply $95$ by a$\blueE{\text{ number less than } 1}?$
$95 \times {\dfrac5{4}}$ :  ${\dfrac54}>1$, so $95$ will be scaled up to a number greater than $95$.
$95 \times {\dfrac4{7}}$ :  $\blueE{{\dfrac47}<1}$, so $95$ will be scaled down to a number less than $95$.
$95 \times {\dfrac12}$ :  $\blueE{{\dfrac12}<1}$, so $95$ will be scaled down to a number less than $95$.
$95 \times {\dfrac88}$ :  ${\dfrac88}=1$, so $95$ will remain the same.
The following expressions are less than $95$ :  * $95 \times {\dfrac47}$  * $95\times\dfrac12$
If we multiply $148$ by $\blueE{\text{any number equal to } 1}$, $148$ will remain the same.  Which expressions multiply $148$ by a$\blueE{\text{ number equal to } 1}?$
$148 \times {\dfrac33}$ :  $\blueE{{\dfrac33}=1}$, so $148$ will remain the same.
$148 \times {\dfrac89}$ :  ${{\dfrac89}<1}$, so $148$ will be scaled down to a number less than $148$.
$148 \times {\dfrac32}$ :  ${{\dfrac32}>1}$, so $148$ will be scaled up to a number greater than $148$.
$148 \times {\dfrac{25}{25}}$ :  $\blueE{{\dfrac{25}{25}}=1}$, so $148$ will remain the same.
The following expressions are equal to $148$ :  * $148 \times {\dfrac33}$  * $148 \times {\dfrac{25}{25}}$
If we multiply $915$ by $\blueE{\text{any number equal to } 1}$, $915$ will remain the same.  Which expressions multiply $915$ by a$\blueE{\text{ number equal to } 1}?$
$915 \times {\dfrac53}$ :  ${{\dfrac53}>1}$, so $915$ will be scaled up to a number greater than $915$.
$915 \times \dfrac{100}{100} $ :  $\blueE{{\dfrac{100}{100}}=1}$, so $915$ will remain the same.
$915 \times \dfrac22 $ :  $\blueE{{\dfrac22}=1}$, so $915$ will remain the same.
$915 \times \dfrac{10}{100} $ :  $\dfrac{10}{100}<1$, so $915$ will be scaled down to a number less than $915$.
The following expressions are equal to $915$ :  * $915 \times \dfrac{100}{100} $  * $915 \times \dfrac22$

If we multiply $610$ by $\blueE{\text{any number less than } 1}$, $610$ will be scaled down to a number that is less than $610$.  Which expressions multiply $610$ by a$\blueE{\text{ number less than } 1}?$
$610 \times \dfrac5{4} $ :  ${{\dfrac54}>1}$, so $610$ will be scaled up to a number greater than than $610$.
$610 \times \dfrac2{3} $ :  $\blueE{{\dfrac23}<1}$, so $610$ will be scaled down to a number less than $610$.
$610 \times \dfrac32$ :  ${{\dfrac32}>1}$, so $610$ will be scaled up to a number greater than than $610$.
$610 \times \dfrac5{7} $ :  $\blueE{{\dfrac57}<1}$, so $610$ will be scaled down to a number less than $610$.
The following expressions are less than $610$ :  * $610 \times \dfrac2{3} $   * $610 \times \dfrac5{7} $

If we multiply $250$ by $\blueE{\text{any number greater than } 1}$, $250$ will be scaled up to a number that is greater than $250$.  Which expressions multiply $250$ by a$\blueE{\text{ number greater than } 1}?$
$\dfrac1{6} \times 250 $ :  ${{\dfrac16}<1}$, so $250$ will be scaled down to a number less than $250$.
$\dfrac9{8} \times 250 $ :  $\blueE{{\dfrac98}>1}$, so $250$ will be scaled up to a number greater than $250$.
$\dfrac9{10} \times 250 $ :  ${{\dfrac9{10}}<1}$, so $250$ will be scaled down to a number less than $250$.
$2\times 250 $ :  $\blueE{2>1}$, so $250$ will be scaled up to a number greater than $250$.
The following expressions are greater than $250$ :  * $\dfrac9{8} \times 250 $  * $2 \times 250 $

If we multiply $\dfrac56$ by $\blueE{\text{any number greater than } 1}$, $\dfrac56$ will be scaled up to a number that is greater than $\dfrac56$ .  Which expressions multiply $\dfrac56$ by a$\blueE{\text{ number greater than } 1}?$
$\dfrac56 \times \dfrac2{2} $ :  ${{\dfrac22}=1}$, so $\dfrac56 $ will remain the same.
$\dfrac56 \times 1\dfrac1{3} $ :  $\blueE{{1\dfrac13}>1}$, so $\dfrac56$ will be scaled up to a number greater than $\dfrac56$ .
$\dfrac56 \times \dfrac68$ :  ${{\dfrac68}<1}$, so $\dfrac56$ will be scaled down to a number less than $\dfrac56$.
$\dfrac56 \times \dfrac7{2} $ :  $\blueE{{\dfrac{7}{2}}>1}$, so $\dfrac56$ will be scaled up to a number greater than $\dfrac56$ .
The following expressions are greater than $\dfrac56$ :  * $\dfrac56 \times 1\dfrac1{3} $   * $\dfrac56 \times \dfrac7{2} $

If we multiply $\dfrac78$ by $\blueE{\text{any number less than } 1}$, $\dfrac78$ will be scaled down to a number that is less than $\dfrac78$.  Which expressions multiply $\dfrac78$ by a$\blueE{\text{ number less than } 1}?$
$\dfrac78 \times \dfrac9{15} $ :  $\blueE{{\dfrac9{15}}<1}$, so $\dfrac78$ will be scaled down to a number less than $\dfrac78$ .
$\dfrac78 \times \dfrac{3}{4} $ :  $\blueE{{\dfrac34}<1}$, so $\dfrac78$ will be scaled down to a number less than $\dfrac78$ .
$\dfrac78 \times \dfrac99$ :  ${{\dfrac99}=1}$, so $\dfrac78$ will stay the same.
$\dfrac78 \times \dfrac43$ :  ${{\dfrac43}>1}$, so $\dfrac78$ will be scaled up to a number greater than $\dfrac78$ .
The following expressions are less than $\dfrac78$ :  * $\dfrac78 \times \dfrac9{15} $   * $\dfrac78 \times \dfrac{3}{4} $
